abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            considered as satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1)
            A performance contract between the Government and a
            Government-owned power company, is not an effective
            mechanism to improve the operational and financial
            performance of the company because it does not provide a
            legal check to enforce the contract. 2) Management contracts
            can be an effective approach to correcting significant
            institutional weaknesses. However, the following conditions
            must be respected to produce results: a) the management team
            must be given sufficient leeway to operate and implement all
            changes to restructure and strengthen the institution; b)
            the duration of its stay should be in line with the severity
            of the problems facing the institutions; and c) it must
            prepare a session/follow up plan which identifies the
            managers who will take over; and a transition plan for the
            actual transfer of management. 3) When the implementation of
            a project experiences serious difficulties, there are
            significant benefits to be derived from staying the course
            while finding ways and means to rework and reengineer the
            project. This involves making adjustments to the project
            design to take into account the changing political and
            economic realities while keeping in mind the project's
            fundamental objectives.
